analysis_panel.title: How to interpret the word cloud analysis
analysis_panel.paragraph_methods: text2sdg combines two approaches: query-based systems (Aurora, Elsevier, Auckland, SIRIS, SDSN, and SDGO) and ensemble models that integrate all systems plus text length.
analysis_panel.paragraph_tradeoff: According to text2sdg documentation, Aurora/Elsevier/Auckland/SIRIS are usually less liberal than SDSN/SDGO. Systematic comparative validation is still limited, so results should be interpreted with caution.
analysis_panel.paragraph_sections: The selected section changes the language being analyzed: competences tends to contain cross-cutting terms, course information better reflects syllabus content, and references mostly reflect bibliographic context.
analysis_panel.paragraph_course_info: To reduce false positives, try stricter criteria (system or section intersection) and always contrast findings with the full course guide.

aggregate_templates.compare: Active comparison: centre "{centre}" ({n_courses_centre} courses) and programme "{programme}" ({n_courses_programme} courses).

system_templates.sys:any: With "{system_label}", an SDG is accepted if it appears in any system. This is the most inclusive view and also the most sensitive to false positives.
system_templates.sys:all: With "{system_label}", only SDGs detected by all systems are accepted. This is more restrictive: it reduces false positives but can miss real cases.
system_templates.sys:ensemble_equal: With "{system_label}", an ensemble model (random forest) combines six systems and text length. This version aims for a general balance between coverage and precision.
system_templates.sys:ensemble_third: With "{system_label}", an ensemble version with an intermediate proportion of synthetic training data is used. It adjusts the sensitivity/specificity trade-off.
system_templates.sys:ensemble_triple: With "{system_label}", an ensemble version with higher synthetic-data weight is used. It yields a more conservative reading, but may miss borderline cases.

section_templates.sec:any: In section "{section_label}", competences, course information, and references are combined. It provides a global view but can mix heterogeneous contexts.
section_templates.sec:all: In section "{section_label}", only terms appearing across all blocks are kept. This is stricter and less prone to false positives.
section_templates.sec:competences: In section "{section_label}", the focus is competences and learning outcomes; cross-cutting terms may repeat across many courses.
section_templates.sec:course_info: In section "{section_label}", title, description, and syllabus content are analyzed. This is usually the most concrete view of what is taught.
section_templates.sec:references: In section "{section_label}", bibliography and references are analyzed. It may introduce documentary-context terms that are not always core course content.

feature_templates.single: Cloud terms are "features" detected in the analyzed texts. Size indicates relative detection frequency.
feature_templates.compare: In each cloud, terms are "features" detected in the analyzed texts. When a term appears in both clouds, it keeps the same color for easier comparison.
feature_templates.default: "Features" are terms automatically detected from the analyzed texts.

analysis_panel.coverage_programme: For the programme, coverage was computed for all system/section combinations. With "{system_label}" and "{section_label}": {with_sdg} out of {total_courses} courses ({coverage_pct}%).
analysis_panel.coverage_centre_unavailable: To compute this percentage by system and section, a programme selection is required (course-level view).
analysis_panel.coverage_unavailable: The percentage of courses with recognized SDGs could not be computed for this selection.
